captions.text: Good morning, John.

Last week I sent you a song about your inflamed
nervous system using the instrumental song
from Calvin Harris's dance song "Summer."

This was a blatant violation of copyright.
I just stole it! But somehow, that's okay.

We live in a brave new copyright world and
the solutions really aren't legal anymore,
they're technological.

So for the people out there who are making
content and are confused about copyright,

this is the bizarre state of intellectual
property in the United States, in four minutes.

Okay. Intellectual property is the idea that
you can own things that are not physical objects,

but are still things. There are three different
ways to own intellectual property in the U.S.

If you just create something, like I'm creating
this video right now, that is protected by

copyright. I own this video. Cause I made
it!

Ideas though, cannot be copyrighted. They
can sometimes be patented. Though obviously

the idea of controlling an idea is a little
bit more weird and scary.

So the U.S. government regulates patents.
You have to apply for them, and be granted
them.

And finally we have trademarks, where you
want to assign a symbol or a set of words

to a corporation or a product. Like the logo
of McDonald's and the word McDonald's and

the phrase "I'm lovin' it" are all trademarked
by McDonald's, so another person can't set

up a restaurant that looks and acts and sounds
like McDonald's but isn't owned by McDonald's.

For the average person who creates or enjoys
creations, copyright is the most interesting

one of these, and it started out very simple.
The idea was hey, I made a bunch of words

in an order. And thus I should be able to
own those words in that order, and someone

else can't come along and put all those same
words in that same order and say "This is
now my book and you can buy it from me."

Which is something that actually used to happen
all the time. To make that law, you say that

you have to have the rights to make a copy
of the thing and you call it copyright.

Simple! No it's not. In order to critique
a work or to critique society, sometimes you

have to use little bits of the things that
society creates. Say I want to make a video

on violence in contemporary cinema. I might
want to use a clip from Reservoir Dogs to

help me illustrate my point. That should be
- and is - legal. It's called Fair Use. Basically

that's the use of copyrighted material for
societal good. And it also has to be inside

part of another work that could not exist
in the same way without the use of that copyrighted
material.

Now there are things that are definitely fair
use and that no one will sue you for, because

any judge in their right mind would call it
fair use. But that doesn't necessarily mean

that it IS fair use; the only person who can
decide whether something is fair use or not

is a judge. Which brings me to the bizarre
state of copyright today, especially on YouTube.

It's much more of a technological system than
it is a legal one because there is too much

content. There is no way a lawyer could
look at every single video that was uploaded

to YouTube! So YouTube has like a robotic
lawyer that looks at literally every single

video that's uploaded to YouTube and then
compares it to a library of, like, just a

massive amount of intellectual property. Every
song ever released, every movie ever made,

every television show ever put on TV - it's
called Content ID and it's actually kind of

a little bit of a miracle. Like what, really,
you can do that?

So if I upload that video of me talking about
violence in contemporary American cinema,

and the Reservoir Dogs clip is in there, the
Content ID will say, "Yes, there is a clip

of Reservoir Dogs," and then they will give
the owner of Reservoir Dogs, whoever that

is, the right to do whatever they want with
that video. They could do nothing, they could

take the video down, or the most likely thing
that they will do is they will monetize that

video for themselves. It's basically like
me paying a retroactive license for the use

of Reservoir Dogs in my video. But I shouldn't
have to do that because it's fair use. So

then I would dispute that copyright claim
saying that it's fair use and then whoa, who

knows where it goes from there? I actually
made a whole video about it on hankschannel,
you can watch it.

But this is why I can basically steal Calvin
Harris's song and not worry about it, because

now I get to pay a retroactive license to
Calvin Harris. I don't get to monetize that

video, Calvin Harris gets the money, but at
least this way I don't have to worry about,

like, trying to make a deal with Calvin Harris's
record label at freakin ten o'clock at night
on a Thursday.

But the big point here is that this is not
the best solution. It's not the most legal

solution, it's not the fairest solution. What
it is, is the most possible solution. Really

the only possible solution. And frankly, it's
kinda cool. I get to violate copyright without

having to worry that my YouTube channel is
gonna get taken down, YouTube gets to not

be sued out of existence, and rights holders
get another alternate revenue stream so they

can have bigger and more fancy yacht parties.
John, I'll see you on Tuesday.

comments.author: Thefaultinourpizza

comments.text:
I've actually been looking into Fair Use Copyright today to see if I'm 
allowed to use a few clips from this very channel in a college documentary! 
I'm making a short documentary about Nerdfightaria and YouTube creators in 
general and being able to use some Vlogbrothers' clips adds so much to it. 
I went to a Nerdfighter meet up in Dublin a few months ago to get some 
interviews and I was really amazed by the unconditional acceptance into the 
community, it's really fantastic.

If anyone's interested in seeing what the documentary turns out like I'll 
be uploading it to my channel when I'm done in a few weeks and I'd love to 
know what the rest of Nerdfightaria thinks :)﻿

comments.author: Bradley Patyk

comments.text:
What are the copyright rules for books or movies based on other books and 
movies (like the book "wicked" based on "wizard of oz" or "the little 
mermaid" based on the grimms brothers' stories)? For some reason it seems 
to me that the creators of these books and movies wouldn't necessarily have 
to pay royalties to the author of the original story (depending on the 
case, obviously). My question: what are the copyright rules for movies or 
books that are loosely based on other stories? ﻿
comments.author: Kathleen Torrez

comments.text:
+Kathleen Torrez It's a bit of a question of degree. Sometimes plot lines 
can be quite similar without it being copying or infringement. If the 
premise is that one is based on another, then it would be a violation of 
the right to derivative works. The derivative works rights I think is a bit 
of an anomaly on the international front - the US may be the only one, or 
one of the few that grants such a right. Other countries require a copying 
of the original story. That being said, you can have copyright in 
well-developed non-generic characters, so using them might be an 
infringement. 

The two old works you cite are in the public domain (Wizard of Oz and The 
Little Mermaid), so you can make any story based on them and it won't be 
infringement. You would also have copyright in your new work, provided it 
is original, but you can't protect the elements that are in the original 
work. You would only have copyright in the new elements you provide.

comments.author: LegendaryKitty63

comments.text:
I pay for royalty free music, whenever I use it on YouTube or for any 
purpose beyond my own computers... then, magically, companies like CD Baby, 
Ioda and others claim the content and, as you so articulately point out, 
monetize work that is NOT theirs exclusively.  While the copyright claim is 
disputed, they earn money from my videos... after the challenge is met and 
the claim "released", they do NOT return the money they made in the mean 
time.  How is this not stealing? What would cause real improvement to this 
process, is if the company who falsely claims rights, were mandated to pay 
back ALL monetized gains during the dispute period... when the results are 
in favor of the challenged channel holder.  Consider the amount we are 
talking about as a YouTube wide dynamic... the money is HUGE... thanks for 
reading my rant :)﻿

comments.text:
Weirdly the individual restaurants, they aren't owned by McDonalds, the 
reasons are the same as why you see ads and deals and sales and things like 
that, but only at participating locations. The owners who live in the area, 
or maybe they just happen to want to run a McDonalds, (PS it is legal to 
say that because it is obvious who I am talking about), they pay a certain 
amount of money to the main corporation, who gives them a special license 
to use their stuff, including recipes, and access to Coca Cola, and other 
things like french fries. This is common is most franchised restaurants 
around the world. It is easier for the corporation to let locals do the job 
and pay up, and the guys at HQ just defend themselves in courts and do the 
lobbying. It also is nice to the locals because they get more business by 
saying they are locally owned and operated. ﻿

Hank says that just by creating an original work it is protected by 
copyright. While you can say that it is and even put the copyright symbol

videos, etc.). Without registering your work (prior to the infringement), 
federal court will throw your case away.﻿

comments.text:
Our world is so obsessed with money. I want to write comics, and eventually 
get into writing animated shows/movies and for video games. If I ever made 
enough money to were I don't need to make anymore for the rest of my life, 
I'd feel no need to charge people anymore for my stuff. I understand I 
still have to work wit other people who'd rightly want compensation, and 
thus I'd still charge for that stuff so they can make money for the work 
they did, but......When is it enough?

When do you make so much money that you feel you have been more then 
compensated for your work, and thus feel you could release it free? And 
releasing it free might bring it to people who'd other wise not ever know 
of you, and potentially purchase future works from you because they liked  
the movie/music/comic by you they got free.﻿

comments.author: Heather Lloyd

comments.text:
This issue is a minefield for us fan vidders. I mean we enjoy a show that 
we bought, watch, discuss, etc. We are fans. We make NO profit off of the 
videos. I have heard that some fan vidders have actually successfully 
applied to become yt partners...but that is the exception.

Most of us do this very tedious task of fan vidding for free. We make a fun 
video for people to enjoy. The hell we have to go through to do it as well. 
But as any artist/creator etc will tell you it's worth it for the final 
result. We have to get the clips, convert them, sit down find the right 
clip, sync it up, test render. Only to have it blocked. Vidding is fun but 
mostly tedious.....

I mean imo it's free advertising for the show/movie/song. I have actually 
seen whole movies posted to this site, but no they are untouched. But a 
less than 5 min video of a show, edited out of order, with the sound taken 
away and a song put on there instead gets taken down!? I mean it's like 
taking a fan made poster away from a fan holding it up at a movie premier. 
Well, they don't OWN those photos do they. They cut them out of 
magazines.....

Also when they block the vid for the song, it's also strange since the song 
IS on youtube! Copyright means that you have a RIGHT to LIMIT the copies of 
something. But a YT vid is INFINITE. You can play it as many times as you 
want. And no music label has ever really taken anything down, so nothing is 
LIMITED. So WHY can't I use the song on my video. It's just disturbing. 
Sometimes the fan made video is a better mv for the song imo. I may be 
biased but I have seen just people comment on fan vids that it's better 
than the 'official' video. But that is a matter of taste...anyways.

Just some common sense would be nice. Fan vidders should apply for a fan 
vid licence or something. Fan vids are GOOD word of mouth for your 
show/movie/music. I have got into and BOUGHT many things since I saw it in 
a fan video. It's time these companies wake up....I am ok with them taking 
ownership of their material. I in NO WAY claim that I own any of these 
shows/music etc that I use. I am ok with them putting ads or blocking them. 
Do what you like you own it sure. BUT it's mean since we are FANS of yours. 
It's just go onto deviantart and there are thousands of drawings of disney 
characters, do they get blocked? THEY drew them but it's BASED on material 
they don't own. Imo as long as you are not making profit off it and doing 
it for fun you should be ok. We have to tread lightly.....﻿

I think that the best way to deal with the content ID system is to make 
disputing the claim easier, and to increase communication between YouTube 
and content creators. Instead of being aloof and making creators afraid 
(especially those that live off of YouTube) they could make it more 
transparent and easier to deal with. An alternative, though, is to create 
jobs for people to look through videos that have been content ID matched 
and check the validity.﻿

comments.author: alyssa MT

comments.text:
Unless of course the copyright holder decides *not* to monetize the video, 
ding you, and shut you down completely. Which happened to my old channel 
that had a few mashups and a video montage set to a Michael Jackson track. 
Sony Music didn't take kindly to this, and rather than make some money out 
of it shut me down.

And in fairness, the MJ track probably wasn't fair use. The mashups though 
were. And so there went my hundreds of thousands of views. Which, when you 
get right down to it, sucks.

Moreover, the way Content ID works, and the whole system seems so 
inherently flawed. I'll get dinged, or even have videos removed because I 
used copyrighted music in the background of what is, essentially, a home 
video for my family and friends that I posted to YouTube because that's the 
easiest way to share videos with people across the globe. And then someone 
else on YouTube will post the entire Lord of the Rings Trilogy (albeit in 
ten minute chunks) or the entire Daft Punk discography and that somehow 
passes by un-noticed.

My home videos with an unlicensed song in the background is no substitute 
to listening/purchasing the real thing. A video with the entirety of Daft 
Punk's Random Access Memories is. There needs to be better systems in place 
to stop one and not the other. And I realize that's a lot easier said than 
done because a robot can't easily tell the difference, but the appeal 
process should be a little more transparent.

And holy crap I just wrote a giant ass youtube comment. I've become one of 
*those* people.﻿
comments.author: Adam Schoales

comments.text:

comments.author: SqueegeeBee

comments.text:
All of my videos use music that is either licensed by the developers of the 
games I am playing or come from Kevin MacLeod or Machinima Sound.  They are 
covered by Creative Commons and specifically called out in the description. 
  Yet, YouTube still allows them to be flagged by idiotic robots and/or 
scammers, who say they own the content...  So, it's a flawed system that is 
being exploited by users who know how the system works and is denying 
people who are following the rules from being compensated for their 
original content.  

Not that I am making all that much off my crap channel, but it's fun.﻿
comments.author: Angry Mongo (AngryMongo)
